Prisca, pictured above, is a group leader and is representing her group, formed by 12 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya. She joined One Acre Fund for the first time in 2010 and decided to represent her group because she wanted to spread the story of One Acre Fund farmers. She is married and has 4 children.

With a portion of this loan, Prisca will not only purchase maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season, but also a solar light. Receiving a solar light as part of her loan means that now she will be able to have an overall improved quality of life. Prisca plans to use the profits she gains this year to buy a cow.

Prisca’s Group will use the inputs received from this loan to plant a total of 4.5 acres of land. They will also receive a total of 10 solar lights.

loans.use: buy maize seeds, fertilizer & a solar light.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fish and seafood in larger volume.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 25 years old, married, and a father of one child. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 to benefit from the trainings, especially on savings management, enterprise development, and financial management. 

He operates a general retail shop and is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy more foodstuffs like sugar, wheat flour, maize flour, and cooking fat, which will enable him earn more income and meet customers' demands. Peter appreciates Kiva and his  lenders and promises to repay the loan well.

loans.use: to buy more foodstuffs like sugar, wheat flour, maize flour, and cooking fat, which will enable him to earn more income and meet his customers' needs.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 55 years old, married, and a father of four children.  He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 and has benefited from the trainings, whereby he has adopted a good saving culture, improved his entrepreneurial skills, and financial management skills.

He grows vegetables such as carrots and cabbages, and also sells vegetable seedlings. He is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy vegetable seeds and fertilizer to increase his stock of vegetable seedlings, to meet his customers’ demands, and at the same time earn more income for his family's basic expenses like food and clothing. He is grateful to Kiva and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy vegetable seeds and fertilizer to increase his stock of vegetable seedlings, to meet his customers' demands and earn more income for his family's basic expenses.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes, 32 years old, is married with five children aged between 3 and 13 years, and three of them go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing rice for the past 14 years. Also, her husband is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy fertilizers to grow rice. The profits from the business will be used to increase her welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers to grow rice.

loans.name: Dora Ligia

texts.es:
Dora es una persona muy simpática y siempre tiene una sonrisa para los clientes que visitan su tienda de abarrotes en el municipio de Caparrapi.

Gracias a su carisma y buen humor se ha podido ganar el corazón y reconocimiento de las personas del sector que siempre prefieren visitar su tienda para adquirir sus productos.

Todos los días trabaja para darles una buena calidad de vida  a sus 3 hijos por los cuales aspira a darles un excelente futuro.

Trabaja sola durante 10 horas todos los días.

Actualmente solicita un préstamo para la compra de surtido de productos de la canasta familiar como granos, abarrotes, golosinas, bebidas, entre otros y de esta forma darle un impulso significativo a su negocio.

El guarda la esperanza de poder continuar con su negocio y así seguir impactando la vida de sus clientes a través de su buen servicio.
texts.en:
Dora is a very likable person, and she always has a smile for the customers who visit her grocery store in the municipality of Caparrapi.

Thanks to her charisma and good temper, she has been able to win the heart and recognition of the people in her sector, who always prefer to visit her store to get her products.

She works every day to give a good quality of life to her 3 children, and she aspires to give them an excellent future.

She works alone for 10 hours every day.

Currently, she is requesting a loan to buy inventory of basic household goods such as grains, groceries, sweets, and drinks, among others.  This way, she will give a significant boost to her business.

She hopes to be able to continue with her business and thereby continue impacting the life of her customers with her good service.

loans.use: to buy inventory of basic household goods such as grains, groceries, sweets, and drinks, among others.

loans.name: Emeline

texts.en:
Emeline is aged 37 years. She is married with seven children aged between 3 and 21 years. Five of them go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing rice for the past 25 years. Her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy fertilizers and pay workers. The profits from the business will be used to buy a piece of land and to pay school fees of her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pay workers

loans.name: Jean Ric

texts.en:
Jean Ric is 28 years old. He is married with three children aged between 1 and 5 years, and one of them goes to school. He is a farmer and he has been growing rice for the past nine years. His wife is a businesswoman. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizer to grow rice. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees of their children and to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to grow rice.

loans.name: Mauricio

texts.es:
Mauricio es un hombre casado, es una persona muy trabajadora y muy responsable, trabajó con su familia en  diferentes negocios donde adquirió experiencia en las ventas. 

Desde hace 2 años inició con una tienda de abarrotes para trabajarla como independiente y  labora desde las 7:00 am a 10:00 pm  
Mauricio sueña con tener un supermercado a futuro, por lo pronto con el crédito solicitado desea adquirir al por mayor una gran variedad de productos como verduras, granos, frutas, hortalizas etc., y poder brindarle a sus clientes artículos de excelente calidad. 

Con este negocio ha podido salir adelante poco a poco e intentara mejorar su vida y la de su familia al lado de la Corporación Interactuar y los prestamistas de Kiva.
texts.en:
Mauricio is a married man.  He is a very hardworking and responsible person.  He has worked with his family in different businesses, where he gained experience in sales.

Two years ago, he started a grocery store to work independently.  He works from 7:00 am to 10:00 pm.

Mauricio dreams of having a supermarket in the future.  For now, with the requested loan, he wants to acquire a large variety of products at wholesale, such as greens, grains, fruits, vegetables, etc., and be able to provide his clients with excellent quality items.

With this business, he has been able to get ahead little by little, and he will try to improve his life and that of his family alongside the Interactuar Corporation and the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy greens, grains, fruits, and vegetables at wholesale.

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary, pictured above, is a group leader and is representing her group, formed by 10 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya. She joined One Acre Fund for the first time in 2010 and decided to represent her group because she wanted to help more farmers. She is married and has four children.

With a portion of this loan, Mary will not only purchase maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season, but also a solar light. Receiving a solar light as part of her loan means that now she will be able to have an overall improved quality of life. Mary plans to use the profits she gains this year to send her children to school.

In total, Mary’s Group will use the inputs received from this loan to plant a total of five acres of land. They will also receive a total of seven solar lights.

loans.use: to buy cost-efficient maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season, as well as a solar light.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 47 years old, married and living with his wife and his five children. He has undergone all Hand in Hand Eastern Africa training on group management, savings mobilization, enterprise development and financial management.

He is involved in a timber-selling business and is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy more timber to increase sales and earn more income to enable him to pay school fees for his children.

He appreciates Kiva and its lenders and promises to repay his loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy more timber to increase sales and earn more income to enable him to pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Moses's Group

texts.en:
Moses is 44 years old and has six children. He is a group leader and is representing his group formed by 14 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya. 

Moses has been farming with One Acre Fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2011. This decision was largely a result of his desire to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods, and although he described his last harvest as poor, he believes he could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside One Acre Fund. Moses also decided to purchase a solar light as part of his loan, which he is very excited about, as it will allow him to have light during dark hours for his children to be able to study.

Obtaining this loan means that Moses's Group will be able to receive a total of 12 solar lights, as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 6.5 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Mwangaza Group

texts.en:
The woman raising her hand holding a passbook is called Lillian. She is 54 years old and a member of Mwangaza Group, which joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 to benefit from training especially on enterprise development and financial management.

Her economic activity is vegetable farming, where she grows vegetables such as cabbages, kale and carrots.  She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy manure which will increase vegetable production and earn more income, which will help her meet her family's basic expenses such as food and clothing.

She is grateful to Kiva and its lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To buy manure which will increase vegetable production and earn more income, which will help her meet her family's basic expenses such as food and clothing.

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en: Zeinab is a 20-year-old Lebanese married woman living with her husband and one child. She is a talented tailor who has been working in this type of business for the past five years to help her husband financially. She produces different clothing designs and makes repairs as well. Today, she wants to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to purchase new textiles to increase her productivity and her income. Zeinab intends to achieve more improvements and enhancements in her life to reach her goals, particularly her financial ones.

loans.use: to purchase new textiles

loans.name: Jeannete

texts.en:
Jeannete is 34 years old. She is married with four children aged between 2 and 7 years old. Two of them go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing rice for the past 13 years. Her husband is also a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy fertilizers. The profits from the business will be used to improve her welfare, pay school fees of her children, and to buy a cow.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers.

loans.name: Olive

texts.en:
Olive is 48 years old. She is married with six children aged between 7 and 25 years old. All of them go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing rice for the past 27 years. Her husband is also a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy fertilizers to grow rice. The profits from the business will be used to buy a cow.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to grow rice.

loans.name: Jean Pierre

texts.en:
Jean Pierre is 40 years old. He is married with six children aged between 2 and 18 years old, and four of them go to school. He is a farmer and he has been growing rice for the past 18 years. His wife is a businesswoman. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizer to grow rice. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees of their children and to buy a house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. loans.name: Casty

texts.en:
Lenders! The above picture presents to you Casty, a very hardworking mother and ambitious go-getter who is 39 years of age and hails from the Chuka area of Kenya, a rural town on the slopes of the famous Mount Kenya. Together with her handsome husband, they support each other as a team and have been doing mixed farming for the past 15 years. Through all those years, she has been able to take care of her family and pay school fees for her children. 

Although this humble mum has been making profits, not everything has been “a bed of roses." She has been facing financial challenges, and because the Chuka area has a ready market for cereals, she is kindly seeking a loan to buy cereals to be able to improve her income level. Casty’s upbringing was challenging and she has been facing many economic problems, but this ever-smiling mum has been making great improvements. She believes that through your loan, she will be able to realize her goal of improving her living conditions and transforming her life. 

Through Juhudi Kilimo, Casty has gone through training and is very honest and disciplined with finances. She hopes that through profits from her business, she will fully pay back the loan. Casty is very visionary and hopes that through accumulated profits she will be able to open a large cereal-selling shop that will boost her income and completely turn her life around. Kindly help her out!

loans.use: To buy cereals to sell

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
The person appearing on the photo is Alex. He is 35 years old and he is single. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in the year 2014 to benefit from the training, especially enterprise development training.

He practices poultry farming and is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy more chickens to increase egg production, to meet his customers' rising demand of eggs and earn more income to pay for the medical expenses of his ailing parents.

Alex is grateful to Kiva and its lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To buy more chickens to increase egg production, to meet his customers' rising demand of eggs and earn more income to pay for the medical expenses of his ailing parents.

loans.name: John's Group

texts.en:
John is a 70-year-old proud father of eight children. He is a group leader, often described as a very reliable person, and is representing his group of 10 farmers in Kakamega North District. Since joining One Acre Fund in 2012, John has noticed that he has been able to consistently feed his family.

John described his harvest as good last year, but believes he can have a better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. He is very excited to also be purchasing a solar light, apart from fertilizer and maize, because he will now be able to have an overall improved quality of life. With the profits from this season’s harvest, he plans to save more money for the future.

With this loan, John’s Group will be able to plant a total of 5.5 acres of land and purchase a total of six solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Bright Sparks School

texts.en:
Greetings from Uganda! This is Sheripha. She is the Head teacher of Bright Sparks School, a mixed school in the Urban area of Mpererwe in Kampala with 80 students. Bright Sparks School has requested a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a UV water-filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students. The school does not currently have access to consistent clean drinking water and therefore has to spend a considerable portion of its budget on firewood, which is used to boil water for the children. Installing a water-filtration system will therefore save the school money in the long term as the cost of firewood will be reduced. The loan will enable the school to purchase a UV water-treatment system with a 450 litre tank, which will be big enough to store clean drinking water for the students every day. 

Bright Sparks School School will repay their loan from their school fees, which they collect each term. Sheripha ultimately hopes that having access to safe drinking water will improve her students' concentration and attendance by reducing the number of children that fall sick from waterborne diseases as well as increase the number of students coming to the school.

loans.use: To purchase a water-filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a water-filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Jason's Group

texts.en:
Jason is 50 years old and has six children. He is a group leader and is representing his group formed by 11 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya. 

Jason has been farming with One Acre Fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2010. This decision was largely a result of his desire to get the best-quality fertilizer and hybrid seeds, and although he described his last harvest as poor due to the effects of MLND (maize virus), he believes he could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside One Acre Fund. Jason also decided to purchase a solar light as part of his loan, which he is very excited about, as it will allow him to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money.

Obtaining this loan means that Jason's Group will be able to receive a total of 8 solar lights, as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 5.5 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
The person in photo is Selina; she is twenty-two years old, married, and blessed with three children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in 2014.

Selina does maize, beans, and poultry farming. She benefited from the HiH EA enterprise and financial development training by acquiring skills that help her run and manager her business well.

She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy fertilizer and seeds that will help increase the quantity and quality of her yield, thus maximizing her profit. Income from her enterprise will meet her family's basic needs, education and medical care.

Selina is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds that will improve crop yield, thus maximize profits.

loans.name: Sele

texts.en: Sele is a married man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is a farmer rearing cattle and growing matooke, groundnuts, cabbages and tomatoes. He is faced with challenges of price fluctuation and weather changes that hinder progress of his business. Besides that, he dreams of laying bricks on a large scale as a way of diversifying his income. He has asked for a loan to prepare the garden for tomato growing.

loans.use: to prepare the garden for tomato growing.

loans.name: Kwa Kakinya S.h.g Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Mbula. She is fifty three years old, married and has four children out of which one child is currently attending school.

She is a member of Kwa Kakinya S.H.G. that joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in the year 2014 to benefit from enterprise development training. She does poultry keeping and is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy more chicken and increase egg production. This will let her earn more income that will enable her to pay for her child's tuition fees.

Mbula is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy more chicken and increase egg production to earn more income that will enable her to pay for her child's tuition fees.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past four years, Rose has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar, soap, salt, sodas, detergent, flour, and toilet paper. 

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar, soap, salt, sodas, detergent, flour, and toilet paper, and will help Rose to generate greater profits and increase income. Rose hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business.

loans.use: buy sugar, soap, salt, sodas, detergent, flour, and toilet paper

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en:
Immaculee is aged 57 years. She is married with 9 children aged between 4 and 30 years. Seven of them go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing rice for the past 35 years. Also her husband is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy fertilizers to grow rice. The profits from the business will be used to increase her welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to grow rice.

loans.name: Mwanahawa's Group

texts.en:
"Mwanahawa, pictured above, is a group leader and is representing her group, formed by 11 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya. She joined One Acre Fund for the first time in 2011 and decided to represent her group because she wanted to help more farmers. She is married and has 4 children.

With a portion of this loan, Mwanahawa will not only purchase maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season, but also a solar light. Receiving a solar light as part of her loan means that now she will be able to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money. Mwanahawa plans to use the profits she gains this year to buy a cow.

In total Mwanahawa’s Group will use the inputs received from this loan to plant a total of 4.5 acres of land. They will also receive a total of 7 solar lights."

loans.use: to buy cost efficient maize seeds and fertilizer for the coming harvesting season, as well as a solar light.

loans.name: Ndumbini S.h.g Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Regina. She is fifty nine years old, married and a mother of three children. One of her children is currently attending school. She is a member of Ndumbini SHG that joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in the year 2014 to benefit from trainings, especially enterprise development training.

She grows maize and beans for sale to earn a living. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy hybrid certified seeds that will enable her increase her production and in the future earn more income and also ensure food security in her community.

Regina is happy for Kiva and her lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy hybrid certified seeds that will enable her increase her production.
